We furthermore obtain $m^2_{\Sigma_8}= [1/3+10 \gamma - \mathcal{O}(\epsilon)] b \lambda^2$ and $m^2_{\Sigma_3}= [4/3- 10 \gamma
+ \mathcal{O}(\epsilon)] b \lambda^2$. Clearly, the requirement $m^2_{\Sigma_3}>0$ is satisfied for $\gamma<2/15$. This shows that there exists a part of the parameter space where $m_{\Sigma_{0}}$ can be at the electroweak scale. This possibility is not in collision with the symmetry breaking chain $SU(5)\rightarrow SU(3) \times SU(2) \times U(1)$ at the classical level.

Singlet field $\Sigma_0$ of mass $m_{\Sigma_0} \simeq 750$\,GeV needs
to couple to vector-like fermions and/or scalars in order to be
produced at LHC and in order to be able to subsequently decay into two
photons. Only then will it be able to help explain observed signal
excess~\cite{Knapen:2015dap,Buttazzo:2015txu,Franceschini:2015kwy}. Vector-like quarks and leptons are frequently used
in GUT model building to address, for example, question of the SM
fermion masses and mixings. The idea is to mix the SM fermions with
one or more of the SM multiplets in these additional $SU(5)$
representations~\cite{Witten:1979nr}. The most commonly used
representations to accommodate vector-like states are $5$-, $10$-,
$15$-, and $24$-dimensional representations. The relevant operators,
at the $SU(5)$ level, are straightforward to write down and we omit them in this note. For explicit proposals to couple vector-like representations to an $SU(5)$ singlet to address observed diphoton excess at $750$\,GeV at LHC in a non-supersymmetric (supersymmetric) setting see Ref.~\cite{Patel:2015ulo} (Refs.~\cite{Hall:2015xds,Dutta:2016jqn}). The use of vector-like multiplets that comprise full $SU(5)$ multiplet(s) of $5$- and $10$-dimensional nature has also been advocated in Ref.~\cite{Ellis:2015oso}.  

Scalar states, on the other hand, are necessary since one needs one or more Higgs doublets to generate fermion masses in the first place. Most commonly used scalar representations in $SU(5)$ are accordingly $5$- and $45$-dimensional ones. The latter contains a leptoquark (LQ) that transform as $(\bm{3},\bm{2},7/6) \equiv R_2$ under $SU(3) \times SU(2) \times U(1)$. This particular field can help generate required signal strength as we show next. (Scalar leptoquark multiplets that transform differently with regard to the SM gauge group have also been proposed to help accommodate diphoton excess in Refs.~\cite{Bauer:2015boy,Hati:2016thk}. Viable scenario with vector leptoquarks has been presented in Ref.~\cite{Murphy:2015kag}.) The operators that yield coupling(s) between a leptoquark $R_2$ and a singlet $\Sigma_0$, at the $SU(5)$ level, are $m 45^{ij}_k\Sigma^k_{~l} \overline{45}_{ij}^l$ and $\sigma 45^{ij}_k \Sigma^k_{~l} \Sigma^l_{~m} \overline{45}_{ij}^m$, where $m$ and $\sigma$ are {\it a priori} unknown dimensionful and dimensionless coefficients, respectively. We find that the trilinear vertex reads $(-m\sqrt{3/10}+3/5 \sigma \lambda)R_2^\dagger R_2 \Sigma_0$.

    on $\sigma (pp \to \Sigma_0 \to \gamma\gamma) \in [5,10]{\mathrm{~{fb}}}$ in
    cyan. Dashed contours denote the total width of $\Sigma_0$
    scalar.}
  \label{fig:constraint}
\end{figure}
We show in Fig.~\ref{fig:constraint} the region in the plane of
$m_{R_2}$ and the coupling $x$ that satisfies the
constraint~\eqref{eq:Excess}. The allowed region suggests a relatively
light LQ multiplet $R_2$ with coupling $x$ of order $1$. Small gluonic
width also guarantees that the bounds from dijet searches are not
sensitive enough to exclude any portion of the parameter
space. The lightness of $R_2$ would potentially cause tension with direct LQ searches, once we allow for arbitrary Yukawa couplings between $R_2$ and the SM fermions. One solution to this issue  that would allow for heavier mediators of $\Sigma_0 \to \gamma\gamma, gg$ is to have additional scalar states with large enough factor $D_{\gamma\gamma}$. For example, suitable candidate that is already contained within the $45$-dimensional scalar representation is the scalar leptoquark with quantum numbers $(\bar{\bm{3}},\bm{3},1/3)$ with $D_{\gamma\gamma} = 49$.

Our proposal opens up the possibility to have one light SM singlet at the electroweak scale in practically any $SU(5)$ setting without the need to introduce {\it ad hoc} scalar state. It is now the question of model building to address the issue of what the very minimal model is that can explain observed excess at the LHC.
